data.text: @mjtimber2 @jsm2334 Apparently only 15% of care home residents in HK are double vaccinated, so there is minimal protection for the most at-risk population.

@jsm2334 Only 30% of over 80 were double vaccinated. 😳 No wonder. And it looks like it was based on generally ok advice of “the sick waiting til they were better to get vaccinated” becoming “don’t get it if you don’t feel in perfect health”. Paying the price now. https://t.co/M5POZORYhq
@jsm2334 @jburnmurdoch If we did not have a vaccine till now , my guess is the ifr of covid would be lower than the ifr of flu till now in young people ( lets say people under 40 )

@jsm2334 @jburnmurdoch Yes vaccine surely helped . 

But chilren are unvaxed and their ifr has become way lower than 2 years age . 
It means the vax did not help with that , probably natural immunity , virus mutation and better treatments did that.

We can say the same thing with other age groups ...

@mjtimber2 Hong Kong is crazy -- not sure if it is pent up susceptibility because they were so committed to zero covid or if they have a nasty sub variant others haven't yet.  There is one mutation dominant in HK but not elsewhere so I sure hope it is not going to repeat elsewhere.

@mobindondon @jburnmurdoch The kids never had IFR higher than flu.
The big difference is the adults, especially older adults, for whom the IFR was much higher for covid than flu pre-vaccine, but since vaccination has come way down (in addition to having different variants -- with Omicron having lower IFR)

@jsm2334 IFR is superceding totals. We have been in two relevant places, Iceland and Denmark, this week. People are actively discouraging ANY measures outside the airport, despite Denmark’s ⬆️ mortality. South Korea is looking decoupled…Hong Kong not so much. https://t.co/pdYjkBNTfI

@mjtimber2 A key caveat is John is talking about infection fatality rate, not population death rates — as he points out Omicron cases were off the charts so even with lower IFR the total numbers of viral deaths were high.

So IFR is only one measure — transmissibility is another
